p.s: In scene 2 (ll. 58-116) of the second act in William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet, Romeo and Juliet talk on the Capulet's residence, Juliet on the balcony, Romeo down in the orchard.
Juliet voices concerns about Romeo he denies.

In the given extract, Romeo and Juliet conversation first concerns Romeo's identity then his safety, with Juliet pointing out that if he was found by the other Capulets, he would be killed but he denies her feaers, saying that his love to Juliet makes him strong enough to take on anyone attacking him and that it was reason enough to put himself into this danger.

When Juliet is not yet convinced he says that if she was to lookslook kindly at him he would be savesafe against any attack and when she replies that she does not want Romeo to be seen there he answers that he can't be seen in the night and that he'd rather be killed by Juliet's family than to not talk to her.
After that Juliet gives up and asks Romeo how he knows about the place to which he replies shortly that he asked for directions and then continues with his confession of love for Juliet.

She then admits to a monologue earlier in the scene in which she confessed her love to Romeo and adds that she would ignore their family feud if Romeo was to love her back honestly and that he shouldn't be taken aback by her quick confession since it does not diminish how seriously she means it.
To confess his love to Juliet, Romeo starts to swear by the moon which concerns Juliet again, thinking that may could mean that Romeo's love is as changing as the moon.
She doesn't want him to swear by anything except maybe himself.
